Award.AwardTitle: Supramolecular Assemblies of Organic Paramagnetic Semiconductors
Award.AbstractNarration:
With the support of the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism Program (CSDM) in the Chemistry Division, Professor Piotr Kaszynski of Vanderbilt University will be developing a new and potentially broad class of organic molecular paramagnetic semiconductors with high molecular and supramolecular structural diversity for electronic applications, such as solar energy harvesting. The centerpiece of the molecular design is a stable heterocyclic radical, which is substituted with groups that promote self-organization of the molecules into layers or columns and formation of liquid crystalline phases. These molecular materials will be investigated for magnetic and photovoltaic properties in which the charge transport is coupled with the magnetic properties of the unpaired electron. The project is interdisciplinary and involves synthesis, extensive characterization, understanding of structure-property relationships (both molecular and supramolecular), and theoretical analysis of new materials. The acquired knowledge will provide tools for fine-tuning of thermal, optical, electronic and possibly magnetic properties of the proposed materials for applications such as energy harvesting.

The work will have a broad impact on several fields of modern chemistry, and will open up access to a potentially large and versatile class of unprecedented liquid crystals, that are of increasing interest to the scientific community and industry as materials with potential applications in molecular electronics and energy conversion. Realization of the project will also impact education and scientific training of the workforce through a diverse educational experience. Professor Kaszynski has been successful in attracting women and minority students to his research group by maintaining a creative and supportive environment that has fostered many careers in science and medicine.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Technological advances in areas such as energy harvesting and information processing depend on availability of new polyfunctional materials with increasing design flexibility. One such area of research involves organic stable radicals, which combine magnetic properties of the unpaired electron and (photo)conductivity of the aromatic systems. In this context we have been exploring self-organizing derivatives of two exceptionally stable, p-delocalized radicals: the verdazyl (I) and benzo[e][1,2,4]triazinyl (II, Figure 1), with focus on their magnetic and conductive properties as a function of molecular and supramoleculr structures.

Systematic investigation of structure-property relationships in a new class of organic paramagnetic semiconductors containing radicals I and II demonstrated their high molecular and supramolecular structural diversity. Thus, substitution of verdazyl and benzo[e][1,2,4]triazinyl heterocycles with groups promoting self-organization of the molecules into of layers and columns and formation of liquid crystalline phases. These molecular materials have been investigated for magnetic and photovoltaic properties, in which the charge transport is coupled with magnetic properties of the unpaired electron.

In the course of this project we have demonstrated that both heterocyclic radicals are viable structural elements of liquid crystalline materials. Using a significant number of derivatives, we have advanced the understanding of structure-property relationships in thermal, optical, and magnetic properties of these unprecedented organic paramagnetic semiconductors. 

Most important accomplishments include

•   The development of functional group transformations in the 6-oxovedazyl and benzo[e][1,2,4]triazinyl systems, which permitted incorporation of these spin-containing fragments to more complex molecular architectures.

•   Discovery of a new, more general method for the preparation of benzo[e][1,2,4]triazinyls

•   Preparation of the first planar analogues of the Blatter radical (the prototypical benzo[e][1,2,4]triazinyl)

•   Demonstration of the first liquid crystalline, both discotic and bent-core derivatives of 6-oxoverdazyl and benzo[e][1,2,4]triazinyl

•   Discovery of new liquid crystalline phases (see Figure 2) and electro-optical switching in these paramagnetic derivatives.

•   Demonstration of ambipolar photocurrent in some liquid crystalline derivatives

•    Development of structure-properties (both thermal and magnetic) relationships in these two families of radicals.

This project has contributed to education of 1 undergraduate and 1 graduate student, 3 postdoctoral researchers and 2 visiting scholars. Our work in the context of this research grant has resulted in 15 peer-reviewed publications and was presented in over 30 conference posters, talks and invited lectures, thus far. Research performed under this grant also stimulated our outreach program and several presentations to the general public of the amazing world of liquid crystals at the Adventure Science Center in Nashville, TN.

Modified by: Piotr Kaszynski

One such area of research involves organic stable radicals, which combine magnetic properties of the unpaired electron and (photo)conductivity of the aromatic systems. In this context we have been exploring self-organizing derivatives of two exceptionally stable, p-delocalized radicals: the verdazyl (I) and benzo[e][1,2,4]triazinyl (II, Figure 1), with focus on their magnetic and conductive properties as a function of molecular and supramoleculr structures. Systematic investigation of structure-property relationships in a new class of organic paramagnetic semiconductors containing radicals I and II demonstrated their high molecular and supramolecular structural diversity. Thus, substitution of verdazyl and benzo[e][1,2,4]triazinyl heterocycles with groups promoting self-organization of the molecules into of layers and columns and formation of liquid crystalline phases. These molecular materials have been investigated for magnetic and photovoltaic properties, in which the charge transport is coupled with magnetic properties of the unpaired electron. In the course of this project we have demonstrated that both heterocyclic radicals are viable structural elements of liquid crystalline materials. Using a significant number of derivatives, we have advanced the understanding of structure-property relationships in thermal, optical, and magnetic properties of these unprecedented organic paramagnetic semiconductors. Most important accomplishments include • The development of functional group transformations in the 6-oxovedazyl and benzo[e][1,2,4]triazinyl systems, which permitted incorporation of these spin-containing fragments to more complex molecular architectures. • Discovery of a new, more general method for the preparation of benzo[e][1,2,4]triazinyls • Preparation of the first planar analogues of the Blatter radical (the prototypical benzo[e][1,2,4]triazinyl) • Demonstration of the first liquid crystalline, both discotic and bent-core derivatives of 6-oxoverdazyl and benzo[e][1,2,4]triazinyl • Discovery of new liquid crystalline phases (see Figure 2) and electro-optical switching in these paramagnetic derivatives. • Demonstration of ambipolar photocurrent in some liquid crystalline derivatives • Development of structure-properties (both thermal and magnetic) relationships in these two families of radicals. Our work in the context of this research grant has resulted in 15 peer-reviewed publications and was presented in over 30 conference posters, talks and invited lectures, thus far. Research performed under this grant also stimulated our outreach program and several presentations to the general public of the amazing world of liquid crystals at the Adventure Science Center in Nashville, TN.
